title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
Assignment 4:
Given a set of Data:


For each variable, compute expected value, variance and standard deviation.

Explain, if it makes sense to compare the standard deviations.

Then, examine the relationship between both variables and compute the covariance and correlation

What measure is easier to interpret? Please discuss your interpretation.

Compute the conditional expected value for:

\(E[income|age<=18]\)

\(E[income|age \in [18,65)]\)

\(E[income|age>=65]\)



Solution:

Code & results:


#Loading Libraries & files:
library(tidyverse)
random_vars <- readRDS("D:/OneDrive/Samantha/TUHH/1stsemester/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics (SE)/Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")
#Viewing the Data:
random_vars



  


#Calculating the Expected Values:
expectedValues <-summarize(random_vars, Age_Expected_Value=mean(age, na.rm = TRUE), Income_Expected_Value=mean(income, na.rm = TRUE))
expectedValues



  


#Calculating the Variance:
variances <-summarize(random_vars, Age_Variance=var(age, na.rm = TRUE), Income_Variance=var(income, na.rm = TRUE))
variances



  


#Calculating the Standard Deviation:
std <-summarize(random_vars, Age_Standard_Deviation=sd(age, na.rm = TRUE), Income_Standard_Deviation=sd(income, na.rm = TRUE))
std



  




The standard deviation is a measure of the proportions of the data being far away from the expected value, therefore, in this case the values stand for age and income and the comparison won’t indicate anything.
Code & results:


#Relationships Between Variables:
cov_corr <-summarize(random_vars, Covariance=cov(age,income), Correlation=cor(age,income))
cov_corr



  




The covariance is the relationship between the two variables and hoe they behave to each other (Measure of linear dependency). Therefore when the value is a high positive value, it means that the two variables are moving into the same direction. But it is not possible to indicate whether the result is high or not as there is no value to compare relative to it. Therefore, using the correlation value is better as the correlation is the standardized measure and is by construction bounded between -1 and 1. The high values in magnitude (close to 1 or -1) indicates very strong linear relationship and the direction of this relation is represented by the algebraic sign.







Note



Interpretation: Since both values of the covariance and correlation are positive, the age and income are moving in the same direction. And using the correlation value which is 0.548, this means that relation falls in the beginning of the of the strong range of correlation.
(According to https://www.tastylive.com/concepts-strategies/correlation#:~:text=Positive%20correlation%20is%20measured%20on,move%20in%20the%20same%20direction. Positive correlation is measured on a 0.1 to 1.0 scale. Weak positive correlation would be in the range of 0.1 to 0.3, moderate positive correlation from 0.3 to 0.5, and strong positive correlation from 0.5 to 1.0).
This means that when the age increases, the income increases and vice versa (not with the same exact rate).



The conditional expected values:


\(E[income|age<=18]\):


#The expected value of the income when age<=18:
condExpectedValue1<-mean(filter(random_vars,age<=18)$income)
condExpectedValue1

#> [1] 389.6074



\(E[income|age\in[18,65)]\)


#The expected value of the income when 18<=age<65:
condExpectedValue2<-mean(filter(random_vars,18<=age & age<65)$income)
condExpectedValue2

#> [1] 4685.734



\(E[income|age>=65]\)


#The expected value of the income when age>=65:
condExpectedValue3<-mean(filter(random_vars,age>=65)$income)
condExpectedValue3

#> [1] 1777.237

title: Probability Theory
text:
1 Basic Rules of Probability

If \(A\) is an event –> \(\overline{A}\) is the complement
with \(P(A)+P(\overline{A})=1\)
Impossible Event: \(P(A)=0\), Certain Event: \(P(A)=1\)
Probability is a real number greater or equal to 0
Total probability is equal to 1
\(\cup\) : Union/ or , \(\cap\) : Intersection/ and
Non-Mutually Exclusive: \(P(A \cup B)= P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B)\) –> Addition Rule




Venn Diagram of Non-Mutually Exclusive Events



Mutually Exclusive: \(P(A \cup B)= P(A) + P(B)\) as the events can’t happen at the same time \(P(A \cap B)=0\)




Venn Diagram of Mutually Exclusive Events



Conditional Probability:
\(P(A|B)\) is the probability of \(A\) happening given that \(B\) has happened
If \(A , B\) are independent: \(P(A|B)= P(A)\) –> Stochastic Independent
\(P(A \cap B)= P(A|B) * P(B)= P(B|A) * P(A)\)
then \(P(A|B)= \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)}\) –> Multiplication Rule



2 Probability Tree

Branches from 1 Node sum to 1
Probability of two consecutive events is obtained by multiplying the probabilities


Assignment 1:
Given the following Probability Tree and with defining being on time as event \(T\), being not on time as \(\overline{T}\), having a change in scope as \(S\) and having no change in scope as \(\overline{S}\)







Solution:
\(P(T\cap S)= 0.3* 0.2=0.6\)
\(P(T\cap \overline{S})= 0.7* 0.6=0.42\)
\(P(\overline{T}\cap S)= 0.3* 0.8=0.24\)
\(P(\overline{T}\cap \overline{S})= 0.7* 0.4=0.28\)



3 Set Theory

Venn Diagrams are used to visualize the occurrence & relationships between events




Generic Venn Diagram



Assignment 2:
Using a random sample of 1000 cistomers of application development company that has developed an app available on either Smartphones “\(S\)”, Tablets “\(T\)” or Computers “\(C\)”. Given the Venn Diagram of the number of customers using each device.







Solution:

The percentage of customers using all three devices: \(P(S\cap T\cap C)=0.5\%\)
The percentage of customers using at least two devices: \(P(S\cap T) + P(T\cap C) + P(C\cap S)+ P(S\cap T\cap C)=7.3+3.3+8.8+0.5=19.9\%\)
The percentage of customers using only one device: \(= 42.3 + 27.8+ 10=80.1\%\)
or \(100 - P\)(at least 2 devices)\(= 100-19.9=80.1\%\)




4 Bayes Theorem
\(P(A|B)= \frac{P(A|B)*P(A)}{P(B)}= \frac{P(A|B)*P(A)}{P(B|A)*P(A)+P(B|\overline{A})*P(\overline{A})}\) –> Bayesian Rule

Assignment 3:
You are quality assurance manager and you want to buy a new tool that automates part of the quality assurance. If the tool finds a product it considers faulty, an alarm is triggered. The seller of the tool states that if a product is faulty, the tool is 97% reliable and if the product is flawless, the test is 99% reliable. Also, from your past experience you know that 4% of your products come out with flaws.


Givens:
\(P(B|A)=0.97\)
\(P(B|\overline{A})=0.01\)
\(P(\overline{B}|\overline{A})=0.99\)
\(P(A)=0.04\)
\(P(\overline{A})=0.96\)


Solution:
Using the Bayesian Rule:

\(P(\overline{A}|B)=\frac{0.01*0.96}{(0.01*0.96)+(0.97*0.04)}= 0.1983471074 =19.83\%\)
\(P(A|B)=\frac{0.97*0.04}{(0.01*0.96)+(0.97*0.04)}= 0.8016528926 =80.17\%\)
Verification: \(P(\overline{A}|B)+P(A|B)=19.83+80.17=100\%\)

These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about 19.83% that the product is flawless and a probability of 80.17% that the product is faulty.

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
Assignment 5:
Given a set of Data:


Read the data and check the dimensions. How many rows and how many columns does the data have?

Use appropriate commands to get a more detailed look at the data. What data types do you see? How do numbers differ from strings regarding their data type?

Run a linear regression. You want to explain what factors are relevant for the pricing of a car.

Choose one regressor and:

explain what data type it is and what values it can take on

what effect is has on the price and what changing the value would have as a result

whether its effect is statistically significant.


Add a variable seat_heating to the data and assign a value TRUE for all observations. Assign it to a new object and run a regression. What coefficient do you get for the new variable seat_heating and how can you explain it?


Solution:

Code & results:


# Load tidyerse package & Data:
library(tidyverse)  

car_prices <- readRDS("D:/OneDrive/Samantha/TUHH/1stsemester/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics (SE)/Causal_Data_Science_Data/car_prices.rds")

#Data Details:
data_dimension<-dim(car_prices)
sprintf("Number of Rows (factors): %d",data_dimension[1])

#> [1] "Number of Rows (factors): 181"

sprintf("Number of Columns (cars): %d",data_dimension[2])

#> [1] "Number of Columns (cars): 22"



Data Viewing:
By having a look at the following data. The factors used are either characters or numeric values. The 2 data types available are chr (character) for strings and dbl (double) for numbers.


#View Data & check Data Types:
glimpse(car_prices)

#> Rows: 181
#> Columns: 22
#> $ aspiration       <chr> "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std…
#> $ doornumber       <chr> "two", "two", "two", "four", "four", "two", "four", "…
#> $ carbody          <chr> "convertible", "convertible", "hatchback", "sedan", "…
#> $ drivewheel       <chr> "rwd", "rwd", "rwd", "fwd", "4wd", "fwd", "fwd", "fwd…
#> $ enginelocation   <chr> "front", "front", "front", "front", "front", "front",…
#> $ wheelbase        <dbl> 88.6, 88.6, 94.5, 99.8, 99.4, 99.8, 105.8, 105.8, 105…
#> $ carlength        <dbl> 168.8, 168.8, 171.2, 176.6, 176.6, 177.3, 192.7, 192.…
#> $ carwidth         <dbl> 64.1, 64.1, 65.5, 66.2, 66.4, 66.3, 71.4, 71.4, 71.4,…
#> $ carheight        <dbl> 48.8, 48.8, 52.4, 54.3, 54.3, 53.1, 55.7, 55.7, 55.9,…
#> $ curbweight       <dbl> 2548, 2548, 2823, 2337, 2824, 2507, 2844, 2954, 3086,…
#> $ enginetype       <chr> "dohc", "dohc", "ohcv", "ohc", "ohc", "ohc", "ohc", "…
#> $ cylindernumber   <chr> "four", "four", "six", "four", "five", "five", "five"…
#> $ enginesize       <dbl> 130, 130, 152, 109, 136, 136, 136, 136, 131, 131, 108…
#> $ fuelsystem       <chr> "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi…
#> $ boreratio        <dbl> 3.47, 3.47, 2.68, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.13,…
#> $ stroke           <dbl> 2.68, 2.68, 3.47, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40,…
#> $ compressionratio <dbl> 9.00, 9.00, 9.00, 10.00, 8.00, 8.50, 8.50, 8.50, 8.30…
#> $ horsepower       <dbl> 111, 111, 154, 102, 115, 110, 110, 110, 140, 160, 101…
#> $ peakrpm          <dbl> 5000, 5000, 5000, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500,…
#> $ citympg          <dbl> 21, 21, 19, 24, 18, 19, 19, 19, 17, 16, 23, 23, 21, 2…
#> $ highwaympg       <dbl> 27, 27, 26, 30, 22, 25, 25, 25, 20, 22, 29, 29, 28, 2…
#> $ price            <dbl> 13495.00, 16500.00, 16500.00, 13950.00, 17450.00, 152…

sapply(car_prices, class)

#>       aspiration       doornumber          carbody       drivewheel 
#>      "character"      "character"      "character"      "character" 
#>   enginelocation        wheelbase        carlength         carwidth 
#>      "character"        "numeric"        "numeric"        "numeric" 
#>        carheight       curbweight       enginetype   cylindernumber 
#>        "numeric"        "numeric"      "character"      "character" 
#>       enginesize       fuelsystem        boreratio           stroke 
#>        "numeric"      "character"        "numeric"        "numeric" 
#> compressionratio       horsepower          peakrpm          citympg 
#>        "numeric"        "numeric"        "numeric"        "numeric" 
#>       highwaympg            price 
#>        "numeric"        "numeric"



Linear Regression:


#Linear Regression: 
lm_dat_original <- lm(price ~ ., data=car_prices)
summary(lm_dat_original)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ ., data = car_prices)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -5662  -1120      0    798   9040 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                        Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)          -36269.965  15460.866  -2.346 0.020354 *  
#> aspirationturbo        1846.206   1041.391   1.773 0.078386 .  
#> doornumbertwo           242.523    571.929   0.424 0.672172    
#> carbodyhardtop        -3691.743   1424.825  -2.591 0.010561 *  
#> carbodyhatchback      -3344.335   1238.359  -2.701 0.007757 ** 
#> carbodysedan          -2292.820   1356.014  -1.691 0.093043 .  
#> carbodywagon          -3427.921   1490.285  -2.300 0.022885 *  
#> drivewheelfwd          -504.564   1076.623  -0.469 0.640030    
#> drivewheelrwd           -15.446   1268.070  -0.012 0.990299    
#> enginelocationrear     6643.492   2572.275   2.583 0.010806 *  
#> wheelbase               -30.197     92.776  -0.325 0.745294    
#> carlength               -29.740     51.672  -0.576 0.565824    
#> carwidth                731.819    244.533   2.993 0.003258 ** 
#> carheight               123.195    134.607   0.915 0.361617    
#> curbweight                2.612      1.781   1.467 0.144706    
#> enginetypedohcv       -8541.957   4749.685  -1.798 0.074219 .  
#> enginetypel             978.748   1786.384   0.548 0.584619    
#> enginetypeohc          3345.252    933.001   3.585 0.000461 ***
#> enginetypeohcf          972.919   1625.631   0.598 0.550462    
#> enginetypeohcv        -6222.322   1236.415  -5.033 1.43e-06 ***
#> cylindernumberfive   -11724.540   3019.192  -3.883 0.000157 ***
#> cylindernumberfour   -11549.326   3177.177  -3.635 0.000387 ***
#> cylindernumbersix     -7151.398   2247.230  -3.182 0.001793 ** 
#> cylindernumberthree   -4318.929   4688.833  -0.921 0.358545    
#> cylindernumbertwelve -11122.209   4196.494  -2.650 0.008946 ** 
#> enginesize              125.934     26.541   4.745 5.00e-06 ***
#> fuelsystem2bbl          177.136    883.615   0.200 0.841400    
#> fuelsystemmfi         -3041.018   2576.996  -1.180 0.239934    
#> fuelsystemmpfi          359.278   1001.529   0.359 0.720326    
#> fuelsystemspdi        -2543.890   1363.546  -1.866 0.064140 .  
#> fuelsystemspfi          514.766   2499.229   0.206 0.837107    
#> boreratio             -1306.740   1642.221  -0.796 0.427516    
#> stroke                -4527.137    922.732  -4.906 2.49e-06 ***
#> compressionratio       -737.901    555.960  -1.327 0.186539    
#> horsepower               10.293     22.709   0.453 0.651035    
#> peakrpm                   2.526      0.634   3.983 0.000108 ***
#> citympg                 -90.352    166.647  -0.542 0.588538    
#> highwaympg              154.858    167.148   0.926 0.355761    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9415, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9264 
#> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


Based on the p-value (a low p-value provides support for the claim that the alternative hypothesis is true instead of the null hypothesis.The alternative hypothesis states, that there is indeed a correlation between the independent and the dependent variable. Because the p-value is low, we reject the null hypothesis and the alternative hypothesis (significant correlation) is true) resulting from the previous summary:

The most significant factors, with the least p-value, affecting the car prices are:



enginetypeohc

enginetypeohcv

cylindernumberfive

cylindernumberfour

enginesize

stroke

peakrpm


These factors are significant as well because the p-value is still less than \(\alpha =0.05\) but not as significant as the previous ones:



carbodyhardtop

carwidth

cylindernumbersix

cylindernumbertwelve







Note



Combining the previous results would summarize the most relevant factors for the pricing of a car to:



Factor
Estimate
p-value




Engine Size
125.934
\(5.00*10^{-6}\)


Stroke
-4527.137
\(2.49*10^{-6}\)


Peak RPM
2.526
\(1.08*10^{-4}\)



The Engine type could be ignored as 2 types of the available in the data set are significant and the other type is with high p-value (not significant). The same applies for the Cylinder Number as 2 Cylinders are significat and the others are less significant.



One Regressor Evaluation:


Engine Size:
By repeating the linear regression with the Engine size factor only, the following results were obtained:


#Engine Size Linear Regression:
lm_engsize <- lm(price ~ enginesize, data=car_prices) 
summary(lm_engsize)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ enginesize, data = car_prices)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -10818.6  -1969.6   -168.6   1494.0  14393.9 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept) -8622.296    873.535  -9.871   <2e-16 ***
#> enginesize    170.064      6.523  26.073   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 3694 on 179 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.7916, Adjusted R-squared:  0.7904 
#> F-statistic: 679.8 on 1 and 179 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


By checking the estimate value it is positive, therefore it indicates a positive relation (when the engine size increase, the price increase).

confint(lm_engsize, level = .95)

#>                   2.5 %     97.5 %
#> (Intercept) -10346.0474 -6898.5441
#> enginesize     157.1932   182.9353

confint(lm_engsize, level = .9)

#>                     5 %       95 %
#> (Intercept) -10066.6082 -7177.9833
#> enginesize     159.2797   180.8487


Then by checking the confidence intervals with different levels, they were completely positive and hence rejects the null hypothesis. That means that we expect an effect in the price when we change the independent variable (engine size) associated with the significant coefficient. This as well is compatible with the p-value criteria (a very low p-value). As a result: Engine size is statistically significant
This is also validated by plotting the results:

#Plot for validation:
ggplot(lm_engsize, aes(x = price, y = enginesize)) + 
geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8)









Stroke:


#Stroke Linear Regression:
lm_stroke <- lm(price ~ stroke, data=car_prices) 
summary(lm_stroke)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ stroke, data = car_prices)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -7743  -5375  -3218   3384  32308 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)  
#> (Intercept)  10504.5     6076.6   1.729   0.0856 .
#> stroke         772.4     1872.1   0.413   0.6804  
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 8087 on 179 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.0009501,  Adjusted R-squared:  -0.004631 
#> F-statistic: 0.1702 on 1 and 179 DF,  p-value: 0.6804

confint(lm_stroke, level = .95)

#>                 2.5 %    97.5 %
#> (Intercept) -1486.438 22495.530
#> stroke      -2921.786  4466.557

confint(lm_stroke, level = .9)

#>                   5 %      95 %
#> (Intercept)   457.433 20551.658
#> stroke      -2322.920  3867.691

#Plot for validation:
ggplot(lm_stroke, aes(x = price, y = stroke)) + 
geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8)









Peak RPM:


#Peak RPM Linear Regression:
lm_peakrpm <- lm(price ~ peakrpm, data=car_prices) 
summary(lm_peakrpm)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ peakrpm, data = car_prices)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -7994  -5379  -2914   3428  32129 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>               Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)  
#> (Intercept) 15062.3973  7417.1744   2.031   0.0438 *
#> peakrpm        -0.3981     1.4266  -0.279   0.7805  
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 8089 on 179 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.0004349,  Adjusted R-squared:  -0.005149 
#> F-statistic: 0.07788 on 1 and 179 DF,  p-value: 0.7805

confint(lm_peakrpm, level = .95)

#>                  2.5 %       97.5 %
#> (Intercept) 426.046744 29698.747876
#> peakrpm      -3.213255     2.417027

confint(lm_peakrpm, level = .9)

#>                    5 %         95 %
#> (Intercept) 2798.76104 27326.033585
#> peakrpm       -2.75689     1.960661

#Plot for validation:
ggplot(lm_peakrpm, aes(x = price, y = peakrpm)) + 
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8)








By repeating the same steps for the 2 other factors individually: Stroke & Peak RPM are not statistically signficant as they have confidence intervals that are not completely positive or negative which supports the null hypothesis and this is also visualized by the plots.

Adding the extra feature (seat_heating):


#Extra Feature
car_prices_extraFeatures <- car_prices %>% mutate(seat_heating = TRUE)
lm_extraFeatures <- lm(price ~ ., data=car_prices_extraFeatures)
summary(lm_extraFeatures)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ ., data = car_prices_extraFeatures)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -5662  -1120      0    798   9040 
#> 
#> Coefficients: (1 not defined because of singularities)
#>                        Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)          -36269.965  15460.866  -2.346 0.020354 *  
#> aspirationturbo        1846.206   1041.391   1.773 0.078386 .  
#> doornumbertwo           242.523    571.929   0.424 0.672172    
#> carbodyhardtop        -3691.743   1424.825  -2.591 0.010561 *  
#> carbodyhatchback      -3344.335   1238.359  -2.701 0.007757 ** 
#> carbodysedan          -2292.820   1356.014  -1.691 0.093043 .  
#> carbodywagon          -3427.921   1490.285  -2.300 0.022885 *  
#> drivewheelfwd          -504.564   1076.623  -0.469 0.640030    
#> drivewheelrwd           -15.446   1268.070  -0.012 0.990299    
#> enginelocationrear     6643.492   2572.275   2.583 0.010806 *  
#> wheelbase               -30.197     92.776  -0.325 0.745294    
#> carlength               -29.740     51.672  -0.576 0.565824    
#> carwidth                731.819    244.533   2.993 0.003258 ** 
#> carheight               123.195    134.607   0.915 0.361617    
#> curbweight                2.612      1.781   1.467 0.144706    
#> enginetypedohcv       -8541.957   4749.685  -1.798 0.074219 .  
#> enginetypel             978.748   1786.384   0.548 0.584619    
#> enginetypeohc          3345.252    933.001   3.585 0.000461 ***
#> enginetypeohcf          972.919   1625.631   0.598 0.550462    
#> enginetypeohcv        -6222.322   1236.415  -5.033 1.43e-06 ***
#> cylindernumberfive   -11724.540   3019.192  -3.883 0.000157 ***
#> cylindernumberfour   -11549.326   3177.177  -3.635 0.000387 ***
#> cylindernumbersix     -7151.398   2247.230  -3.182 0.001793 ** 
#> cylindernumberthree   -4318.929   4688.833  -0.921 0.358545    
#> cylindernumbertwelve -11122.209   4196.494  -2.650 0.008946 ** 
#> enginesize              125.934     26.541   4.745 5.00e-06 ***
#> fuelsystem2bbl          177.136    883.615   0.200 0.841400    
#> fuelsystemmfi         -3041.018   2576.996  -1.180 0.239934    
#> fuelsystemmpfi          359.278   1001.529   0.359 0.720326    
#> fuelsystemspdi        -2543.890   1363.546  -1.866 0.064140 .  
#> fuelsystemspfi          514.766   2499.229   0.206 0.837107    
#> boreratio             -1306.740   1642.221  -0.796 0.427516    
#> stroke                -4527.137    922.732  -4.906 2.49e-06 ***
#> compressionratio       -737.901    555.960  -1.327 0.186539    
#> horsepower               10.293     22.709   0.453 0.651035    
#> peakrpm                   2.526      0.634   3.983 0.000108 ***
#> citympg                 -90.352    166.647  -0.542 0.588538    
#> highwaympg              154.858    167.148   0.926 0.355761    
#> seat_heatingTRUE             NA         NA      NA       NA    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9415, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9264 
#> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

lm_seathaeting <- lm(price ~ seat_heating, data=car_prices_extraFeatures)
summary(lm_seathaeting)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ seat_heating, data = car_prices_extraFeatures)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -7881  -5390  -3019   3431  32401 
#> 
#> Coefficients: (1 not defined because of singularities)
#>                  Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)       12999.4      599.7   21.68   <2e-16 ***
#> seat_heatingTRUE       NA         NA      NA       NA    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 8068 on 180 degrees of freedom


By adding the extra feature seat_heating to the factors and performing the linear regression again either with all factors or with the extra factor added, we get the seat_heating coefficient as NA (missing value). This value is logical because the factor in this data set was assigned to true always and hence not affecting the price. This is also validated by the plot.

#Plot for Validation:
ggplot(lm_seathaeting, aes(x = price, y = seat_heating)) + 
geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8)

title: Regression Discontinuity

title: Probability Theory
text:
Branches from 1 Node sum to 1
Probability of two consecutive events is obtained by multiplying the probabilities


Assignment 1: Using the following Probability Tree and with defining being on time as event \(T\), being not on time as \(\overline{T}\), having a change in scope as \(S\) and having no change in scope as \(\overline{S}\)






\(P(T\cap S)= 0.3* 0.2=0.6\)
\(P(T\cap \overline{S})= 0.7* 0.6=0.42\)
\(P(\overline{T}\cap S)= 0.3* 0.8=0.24\)
\(P(\overline{T}\cap \overline{S})= 0.7* 0.4=0.28\)
